job_title: Financial Analyst II in Seattle, WA
pros: Amazing learning opportunity as you are drinking from a massive fire hydrant. There are many situations to interact with brilliant people and have interesting conversations to come up with solutions and metrics for the business. The resources that are available are vast with a knowledge repository, courses, and mentor sessions to aid in your career journey. Working here is a definite boost to your resume given the fast-paced work culture and the amount you need to do to succeed.
cons:
To succeed and advance, you will not have a life outside of work. I suggest reading the New York Times article (originally from 2015), although some things have changed, it is essentially the same yet more subtle to avoid the publicity. In my situation with my work hours and demands, I lost a lot of the stuff I had going into the job (friends, relationship, family rapport, etc.), making the opportunity not worth it if I had the chance to do it again.

Expect to answer emails quickly regardless of the time and with the typical day being constant back-to-back meetings from 9a to 5p, the only time to do your work is in the evenings and early mornings. If you slack in the slightest the political nature of the culture will leverage this going forward unless you quickly switch teams but you do need to persuade your manager for approval to switch.

Vacations are not truly a break from work, only a different working location, you will still be doing work and answering emails otherwise you will get cut with the "rack and stack" performance reviews. Being constantly berated and belittled is a normal occurrence although falls in the grey area in the view of HR for acceptable practices. Throw out normal business practices/standards as they are viewed as unprofessional and roadblocks to achieve the ridiculous goals and metrics.

review_title: Relatively good pay, but incredibly stressful and no life.
pros:
One of the main positives I have about Amazon is the relatively good pay when compared to other warehouses in my area. Of course the pay is still relatively low when compared to other industries (and that is not good), but Amazon definitely pay a bit more, which is a benefit and all the added bonuses are beneficial too. 

I was also surprised with the training. It is relatively good. Of course it's not the best, but when it comes to my experiences of warehouse work, the training is pretty good. They make sure that you fully understand what to do before signing you off your three days of training and there really is a huge focus on health and safety.
cons:
When you work at Amazon you are worked TO THE BONE. It feels like you are in school (and on the bad days it feels like you are in prison or at some labor camp). It really is a stressful position where you are on your feet and performing repetitive tasks for extremely long hours. Some jobs are more strenuous than others too. I worked in shipping, which I feel is less stressful than packing items into boxes. 

The PPE we are provided with is incredibly poor. Amazon need to source more comfortable shoes that employees can wear as walking around the warehouse really is a tiring job. 

The 10-hour workdays are too just much, especially as you only get one hour of break a day (30 mins in the morning and 30 mins in the afternoon). By the end of the shift you are absolutely worn out, depressed, aching and you just want to go home. The amount of hours I work a week really puts stress on my relationship and I feel as though I don't have a life; like I just live to work. I feel so miserable working for Amazon. No fun days during peak can make me feel otherwise.

job_title: Warehouse Associate in Union City, GA
pros: Pay was good; Shoe Allowance and benefits were a plus. Voluntary Extra Time.
cons:
Favoritism. Short breaks...Screw you with “Flex Scheduling”. Deceptive
Set you up for failure. Zero communication absolutely none. Unfair point system

NUMBER 1: 

Amazon will work you to death then dance on your corpse if you allow them to. I will say this very carefully. At Amazon YOU ARE NOT A HUMAN BEING. YOU ARE A NEGATIVE NUMBER. 

NUMBER 2:

Flex Scheduling was unfair designed to set you up for failure; they change your hours without telling you then punish you if management tells you to clock out early. I took a lot of Extra Time before my first day. I ended up working in inbound those days. Inbound wanted me in inbound. Management wanted me to scan when there was no room for scanners they sent me back to inbound. Then punished me for it. Told me I had to scan for 2 weeks EVEN after scanning for four days already. Then told me they were never going to train me for inbound. Whatever no big deal. But they treat everyone like a child. It’s demoralizing and demeaning. My real issue though is with their scheduling. They add time to your schedule in a sneaky and nefarious way designed to fast track you out the door. They would wait until after my break then add time to my schedule because they knew I couldn’t check my phone. Then they don’t tell you when you’re supposed to clock out. So if a supervisor tells you to clock out at a certain time if it happens to be more than 5 minutes before your scheduled clock out time. They give you a half attendance point. 6 points and you’re fired. They don’t care and won’t fix it. In fact I think they do this on purpose to keep the door revolving so they can brag about constantly hiring people. 

NUMBER 3: The lies; retaliation; hostile work environment 
Dangerous work conditions 

You have to deal with everyone being a liar and out to screw you over. At least that’s what I was told. 
They create an ethics line so they know who to fire 
If you make a report with the ethics line they will know and will fire you for it

pros:
I spent nearly 8 years at Amazon across retail, customers services and operations. I loved it, the pace the ability to make change, the adrenaline from having a lot of quite interesting stuff to do and not enough time to do it in.

I joined the company young, single and care free, able to devote the hours needed and the values matched my values so it was a great match. Then I got married, had kids and the Amazon love affair turned poisonous. I was no longer able to devote the time and effort required, I still did about 2 hours extra every day but it wasn't enough... and that's where I come onto...
cons:
The cons. Jeepers, the cult atmousphere is strong! The place would hire people who maybe didn't fit the values as much as I did, they would then have an awful time as the business is so values driven and they'd be spat out the other end. One year, the team I sat in was supposed to be 7 strong, in January, it was just me, we went through the next 12 months hiring and loosing people until the next January... it was just me. 

At the senior level, there is a lot of incredibly strong people, awesome leaders but they struggle with listening and accepting pushback which has lead to some godawful decisions in my time there, particularly my final few years operating at a senior level. 

My advice to anyone thinking about joining at a senior or manager level or above, do it if your single or have an incredibly supportive other half. This isn't true for all parts of the business but is for the majority of the retail, AWS, operations and customer service sides of the business.

pros: You receive a weekly wage
cons:
You don't get breaks for your entire 6/8.5 hour shift. You aren't allowed to sit down or drink water during the shift, either. The job is much more manual than they let on, you do on between 18000-25000 steps a day and lifting up to 22kg persistently. I've seen people collapse on the shift. There is no health and safety, someone hurt their foot and a supervisor said 'what do you want me to do about it?' 
Supervisors in general talk to you like your a dog. Absolutely zero respect to employees whilst they sit, with heaters, bottles of water and amazon-gifted snack, and shout at you through a megaphone.

If you deny overtime on your days off twice, you are sacked. The bags we receive back from deliveries are often filled with food waste, and once i found a bottle of urine. Non of these issues are taken seriously, but you regularly get rude text messages about not sitting down. 
There is next to no covid protection. You are made to wear a mask all day, but most people wear them incorrectly. The aisles are full of people you have to squeeze by all day. 
Depending on when you were employed, you get differing bonuses. Long term employees get nothing, some get up to £100 a week for attendance alone. 

The shifts get changed about every 10 days/2 weeks. You don't get paid night hours for starting before 6am either, despite it being a legal obligation. I've been there around 3 weeks, they have changed my shifts twice already. If you have a problem with it, you are told to leave.

What i can't stress enough is just how utterly vile supervisors talk to employees. They get worked like donkeys and spoken to like dogs.

review_title: Not too bad to work for
pros:
I worked for PMP in the Amazon Gourock warehouse throughout lockdown.

I was quite nervous before starting due to reading a fair amount of negative press online about the way workers were treated. I'd read stories of people peeing in bottles because they couldn't go to the toilet and others of being sacked for being too slow.

I appreciate things were a bit different because of the pandemic however it was nothing like the negative reviews I'd read. There had been some things put in place to help workers such as longer breaks and increased wage per hour.

PMP themselves were fine. They got me signed up and working quickly. Once you're in the door you don't really deal with them again. There was a young guy working for them who was a total sex pest. So I imagine if you were a girl worker then you got quite a lot of PMP attention. They paid on time and it was all very efficient. 

The work itself was monotonous. I was a picker and spend my hours walking around piling stuff onto my cart and then dropping it off. It kept me busy and I had no problem keeping up with the numbers you were required to hit. I think some negative reviews will come from people expecting to be perhaps be rewarded or thanked for working hard. This does not happen. I worked my backside off and had very high numbers but the only consolation was that the lady that comes round to tell you off, didn't come to have a "chat" with me. 

Amazon provided masks and took Covid seriously. At first they were using such equipment to check peoples temperatures. On one occasion the temp reading was me suggested I was stone cold dead. It was comical and the guy just waved me in. Another time I set off the alarm as I'd been sitting in direct sunshine for 5 minutes. Again they waved me in.

There was a few times when people spoke to me in a manner that was just not acceptable. I let them know this and did receive apologies. There was a lack of clear communication for instance as I was on a specific shift pattern I would miss notifications that others received and doors to use and ways to enter and exit. If I did it wrong I got shouted at and this is when I challenged them. 

Amazon and PMP got me through the pandemic and I'm grateful for that. I'd work for them again for sure.

At the end of my time with them I'd just finished my 4 day bock to return home to a family member showing Covid symptoms. I let PMP know this and they told me to get tested and come straight back to work. This bothered me as the NHS had literally just told me not to leave the house. There was a mishmash of information and I stuck to what the current government guidance was. I feel PMP messed up here but such is life.

One other negative about PMP is that they sign you up to their pension scheme. Now this was introduced to protect people etc but my issue with it was that you could not easily remove yourself from the scheme. I read the agreement carefully and it supplied an email address. It stated email this address to remove yourself and when I did, they replied saying it's not us who deal with it and proceeded to say they couldn't help. So What I am saying is that some of their blurbs in the contract were incorrect.

I you're considering working for them I'd say why not! PMP get you signed up quickly and pay on time. Amazon full time staff are friendly and helpful enough. I was met with some aggression at points however I think this was down to the current situation. People were more stressed as isles could not be shared etc and packers were annoyed and pickers etc.

Packing looks like a truly awful job.

Picking is fine and is good exercise.

Stowing was very easy. 50% of the time there was no work and they'd stand around in groups for hours.

The ideal would be to mix up shifts with a bit of each job. That would help retain staff I would suspect.
